Package org.jtrim2.cache

Interface ObjectCache

All Known Implementing Classes:
MemorySensitiveCache
public interface ObjectCache
Defines a cache of some java objects. This cache is designed to be used to cache objects retaining considerable memory. Although cache implementations must allow any objects to be cached, caching objects comparable to a VolatileReference in size is useless and will only cause more memory to be used.

Every implementation of this object cache must allow any java object to be cached, however they may prefer some over others (the preference is implementation dependent) and can handle such objects more efficiently.

This cache returns VolatileReferences of objects and these volatile references can be used to access cached datas.

The most basic implementation of this cache is javaRefCache() and this implementation should be used by default if there is no specific cache is available.

Thread safety

Implementations of this interface are required to be completely thread-safe and the methods can be called from any thread.

Synchronization transparency

The methods of this interface are required to be synchronization transparent, so they can be called in any context (e.g.: while holding a lock).
See Also:

  • Method Details

    • javaRefCache

      static ObjectCache javaRefCache()
      Returns an ObjectCache implementation which is directly backed by the JVM. This class can be used to provide volatile references created by GenericReference.createReference through the ObjectCache interface.

      This implementation of ObjectCache is intended to be used where an ObjectCache is required but there is none available.

      Returns:
      an ObjectCache implementation which is directly backed by the JVM. This method never returns null.

    • getReference

      <V> VolatileReference<V> getReference(V obj, ReferenceType refType)
      Returns a new volatile cached reference of the given object. The passed object will be cached at the discretion of the implementation.

      If the implementation chooses the cache the passed object, the volatile reference should keep returning the cached object (unless the reference was cleared) as long as the cached object is in the cache. In case the cached object is removed from the cache for any reason, the volatile reference may keep returning it (e.g.: using soft or weak references).

      Note that clearing the reference will not necessarily remove the object from this cache but implementations should (but not required) do so if every returned volatile reference of the passed object is cleared.

      Note that in most cases the used reference type is recommended to be ReferenceType.WeakRefType or ReferenceType.SoftRefType, so the object will effectively remain cached unless the JVM decides that it needs more memory. The main reason not to use them is that these references (if reachable) will cause a small performance penalty for the garbage collector.

      Type Parameters:
      V - the type of the cached object
      Parameters:
      obj - the object to be cached. The returned volatile reference will return this object or null. This argument can be null but in this case the returned reference will always return null and is effectively useless.
      refType - the type of the reference to be used if the passed object was removed from this cache. Implementations are expected to honor this argument but may ignore it if they document it so. This argument cannot be null.
      Returns:
      the volatile reference of the passed object (obj). This method must never return null.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - thrown if the reference type is null
